comments.commentBody:
Um, just out of curiosity, what is it that California should have done 4 years ago that would have significantly changed the situation today?

As you might know, about 80% of the state's water supply goes to agriculture. Sauteing, rather than boiling, ravioli in restaurants and that sort of thing is nice, but it doesn't amount to much in the grand scheme of things. In order to make a dent in the current water shortage, the state would have had to make significant cutbacks to agriculture 3-4 years ago. At that time, it was still possible that a wet winter would re-flll the state's reservoirs, and thus no one was eager to reduce the state's supply to farmers, which would have meant lost jobs and higher prices for consumers.

I have a great deal of sympathy and compassion with the Greeks, and I would not defend the creditors in this mess.  But I believe we can surmise what will happen next precisely upon the words that come out of Mr. Tsipras.  If he talks about Greek reform, such as with an open discussion of tax collection performance and a plan on how to jump start that, then Greece will start improving.  If he talks about democracy and solidarity and insolvency, Greece is doomed.  The tragedy is that the Greeks themselves have not yet understood that no one is going to pay for their pensions anymore, and that they have failed as a democracy to handle financial matters.  Only after the Greek conversation focuses to governance issues can they begin to change.

Your headline is wrong. Greece has been in a disaster since 2008. They don't have much to lose. If the rest of Europe doesn't give big time, almost wiping out the debt, going back to the drachma is the way to go. I think this course is best in any case, but it would be better to do it in an orderly fashion.

Your columnist Krugman, the world's preeminent macroeconomist, has come around to this. It's time to blow up the euro.

Remember eastern Europe after the Wall came down. Hard times for several years, but now they are much better off. The same applies here.
Unifying Europe with one currency was an unworkable, ill-fated idea from the start.  But too lucrative to those in charge to pass on.

If Germany succeeds with Greece American capitalism fails miserably. This is the financial equivalent of Germany's military invasion of Poland. Expect this time it not the industrial companies leading the charge but the financial institutions.

Greece's best choice is Yuanization - using Yuan instead of Euro. Issuing micro-sovereign bonds (1000 Yuan face value). This would be the modern dollarization with a twist.

Once BRICS overtake global economic leadership the game will be over for financial global takeover plans of Dollar and Euro.

Even if we want to help, how can you take good money and send it to a country that leaves 90% of its applicable taxes uncollected?  It's simply not prudent to be such a creditor.  And then Greece screams bloody murder and attacks you as a terrorist when you don't send more.  We are better off sending goods and relief supplies, I have come to the sad conclusion.  Until Tsipras tells us how he's gonna raise tax receipts real fast, and not much else please, Greece is headed into the abyss of bankruptcy and hyperinflation.
Democratic, you said it.  The Greeks voted for the professional clowns that got them into this mess and for the amateur clowns running the country now, and they may reap a bitter harvest.

Personally I think there are a bunch of people here in the U.S.  who, just as they make mint anytime anything of note - or of no note at all - must be reported to friends/family, are making mint through the Internet buzz of this crisis.  Time to give something back. Let our top tech outfits kick in a couple hundred million apiece (that's their Starbucks money), save a national economy, prevent a few thousand suicides, spare a few million kids lives of utter inexorable unrelenting agony and torment. Call it 'connecting and sharing' with one's money where one's slogan is.

Those 'gifts' were gifts to private banking interests to keep them from collapsing under the weight of their own high-risk investments and speculation. That risk was then transferred to the public under the guise of 'loans' to Greece, only 9% of which went into the Greek economy; the other 91% went straight back to the banks.

11 MILLION EU FAMILIES
WILL HAVE TO GIVE EVERY GREEK MAN, WOMAN AND CHILD
A GIFT OF 1 WHOLE YEAR OF THEIR LIVES AND OF THEIR WORK!

When is enough, enough already? Greeks “borrowed” €34,000 euro for each man, woman and child. The debt, forgiven different ways, becomes a Gift of €367 billion euros!

11 million EU families will have to pay for the Gift to 10.75 million Greeks! Since average French/German take home pay is €35,000 euro, 11 million families will have to work one whole year of their lives to pay off their “gift”!

The first gift was €107 billion euros.This is a 60% haircut on the original € 200 billion euro debt. The next gift is €120 billion euro of the current €240 billion euro loans (less the IMF amount of 20 billion). By its “repayment” terms it’s a gift called a loan.

The third gift to Greece is €110 billion given to Greece through the back door by the ECB. This is for magical paper, Bank of Greece worthless paper supported by Greece worthless paper. The next gift is “small change” of € 30 billion euros. This comes if the EU gives another “loan” of some € 50 billion euros in the current crisis. Figure the terms as no better than existing “gift–loans”, making for an immediate gift of €30 billion the second it is made.
And the EU still wants to negotiate!

Does it really take an Einstein to recognize that “Insanity [is the EU] doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results”? And Americans are crazy?
Time to cut the umbilical cord and let Greece go!

I think the Greek drama has occurred precisely because Europe is not a federal republic like the USA.  Each member state is autonomous in its social policy.  Those differences, for example, cause each EU member state to have different public pension plans.  But when one sovereign nation goes under, their retirees don't get paid.  In the USA this doesn't happen with a single state ever.
Don't want to burst your bubble, but Greece already got a 50% debt relief in 2012 something most US commentators seem to miss.

I see many efforts to contrast a reluctance to forgive Greek debt today to willingness to forgive Germany's back in 1953.  Neither case involves debt holders considering forgiveness out of warm-hearted humanitarianism.  In 1953 in the midst of the Cold War, a failed West Germany posed risks to NATO and the economic failure of a major nation risks to all of Europe.   In addition, it seemed likely that given debt relief, the German economy would thrive.  Fast forward to Greece -- far less risk an damage from Greek bankruptcy and a low likelihood that debt relief will be used intelligently by the incompetent Greek government and corrupt Greek financial, economic and legal system.
I think we should deal with debt relief, but only if some autonomy in tax collection is ceded by Greece to the EU, and subito.  We have come to the point of cutting up Greece on the table.

Well, to be fair, the world doesn't really need to worry about Greece starting WWIII. After WWII, a real concern of the Allies was that Germany, if faced with excessive debts again, would destabilize again, and take the world off a cliff again. Also, keep in mind that after the war, the Allies did take quite a bit of territory back from the Germans along with a lot of assets, and the vast majority of the intellectual talent in Germany.
In this case the capitalists are the blue-collar worker of other countries.

The Greeks want to be given everything and do nothing.  Retire with generous benefits at 50 - no problem.  Endless bailouts - no problem. Capitalism has raised billions of people out of poverty but the secret is that people need to work.
This is predatory capitalism at its best. It's not about what ordinary people do or want; it's about the capitalists running the show and imposing their will.

Lenders aren't trying to "help" Greece; they're profiting off of Greece. And Greece has been liberalizing its economy for years. The results are unambiguous: 25 percent unemployment, increased suicides, increased hunger and homelessness, increased anti-immigrant violence, and the increased spread of preventable diseases including HIV and malaria.

The federal government does not make the wealth that it siphons to many, many states. It taxes people in all the states and DC and then some of those states end up with less than they had within their borders before April 15 every year. People like to joke about NJ, but NJ gives 40% of its citizens' wealth to the poorer states. Illinois, gives up 25% annually to the poorer states, Cal and NY lose 20%. That's money that could have made public services and infrastructure much, much better in those states. Since 1913 and the Constitutional Amendment that created the fed. income tax its been that way. The kudos don't belong to  Washington, they belong to NJ, IL, CA, NY etc. They support this system.

From what my contacts in those countries tell me, the people of Ireland, Portugal, and Italy would beg to differ; they are not doing as well as the propaganda pushed by the creditors would have you believe. The 'austerity forever' bloc simply needed a contrvied 'success story' or two to prove their failed economic policies.

The big difference between the German debt being cut after WW2 and the Greece situation now is that Germany already had the structure needed to make it on their own. They had industry, a new functioning government, infrastructure, and let's not forget - Europe and the U.S. needed a strong Germany as a barrier against the Soviet Union, so the debt wasn't cut for the sole purpose of helping the German people. So the debt was cut and Germany did their own thing to get out of the miserable situation they were in.

Greece does not have that structure at the moment. The Troika were put in place to help them build the structure that is necessary for them in the future to make it without loans. If the debt was cut now before all these measures are in place, what reason does the Greek government have to change what brought them into the situation in the first place? It was never a question of whether the debt will be cut for Greece, it was always a matter of when. That so-called "austerity" helped other countries such as Ireland, Spain and Portugal, so it can't be all that wrong. And what would these countries say if Greece was dealt with in a completely different way? If Greek debt was cut now, that would not be the end of the line; Greece would need more loans even after that.

Everyone praises the Greek referendum - but one country cannot possibly dictate to the EU - and other democratic nations - what the terms should be for giving them more money.

With all the love for the Greeks and the Germans, the Greeks don't appear ready to take their chance.  The Greeks had 5 years to improve tax collections, but are only at 10% of assessed taxes that flow in.  The Greeks never talk about that malfeasance.  I agree with debt relief, but only when Greek tax receipts rise very fast.  That is theoretically possible and is also the best legal and moral outcome for all, if you think about it.  I think Tsipras could make a case to the world for how to do it, but he talks about other stuff that is less relevant.  Very sad.

It is not accurate to call PM's Tsipras Syriza party "left wing" as the article does -- it is an insult to ordinary left-wing parties.

Syriza is an acronym for the Greek words meaning "Coalition of the Radical Left" (Greek: Συνασπισμός Ριζοσπαστικής Αριστεράς, Synaspismós Rizospastikís Aristerás).

Syriza's radical left policies are opposed by most of the ordinary left-wing parties in the Euro Zone.

while the EU stands its ground Putin is watching and licking his chops, he will be overjoyed, if the EU drops Greece-it will be the first of many cracks to come in the European Union, there is a German saying, translated into English" when 2 people argue, the 3rd will be happy" that 3rd is Putin.
@Stonezen You blame the victim?

@TR2 The idea of the EU was to form a kind of United States of Europe. That would require the kind of solidarity with the whole European project that Germany is contemptuous of. They'd rather loot Greece than save Europe.
Nice - you managed to make this anti-Obama. Now, if only the Greeks had the right to bear arms, right?

Because scenarios like that can and do happen all over the world. And as we live in the 21st century and social justice is such a big thing, Greece's pretenses are outrageously injust to all the nations who have to pay for their life style.

Take a breath. All this talk of evil this and bad country that. Not necessary. Greece can afford what Greece can afford and 60% of its people have told the world they don't care that much. That those total loan and repayment figures appear no where in this periodical or most others says to me that we are still at the "tyre kicking" stage in this "negotiation". As the buyer of the "car deal" Greece is  clearly under no pressure to get "transport" and seems to have no desire to go anywhere. Why do you care so much if some Euro-fund takes a bath or a few million people have a particular standard which you don't understand.  Its just  the Europeans.
